nodes.text: High public and external debt levels are systematically associated with lower economic growth and, in some cases, higher inflation across countries and history
We assemble a new multi-country historical dataset on central government (gross) debt covering 44 countries and about 200 years with over 3,700 annual observations

For advanced economies (20 countries, 1946–2009), median GDP growth is similar across low to high debt ranges but falls about 1 percentage point when public debt exceeds 90 percent of GDP; mean growth falls by about 4 percentage points
For emerging market countries, public debt above 90 percent of GDP is associated with notably lower median and mean GDP growth and also with much higher inflation levels

Gross external debt (public and private) in emerging markets shows lower growth thresholds: growth deteriorates when external debt exceeds about 60 percent of GDP and worsens sharply above 90 percent, sometimes producing outright declines
The dataset also includes gross external debt series (available more recently) and separates analysis for central government debt and external debt where possible
Evidence from long-run (one to two centuries) country series yields similar conclusions: average growth ~1.7 percent when debt exceeds 90 percent vs ~3.7 percent when debt is below 30 percent

The inflation response differs by country type: advanced economies show no systematic link between high public debt and inflation as a group, while emerging markets exhibit much higher inflation at high public debt levels, consistent with fiscal dominance
Historical episodes of deep financial crises are followed by rapid public debt increases and extended macroeconomic adjustment, including slow growth and deleveraging
More than half of external debt defaults in emerging markets since 1970 occurred at debt levels near or above 60 percent of GDP, matching the identified external-debt growth thresholds
Available external debt time series for advanced economies are too short (beginning around 2000) to estimate long-run external-debt thresholds for advanced countries

Conclusion: Across advanced and emerging economies, public debt/GDP above roughly 90 percent is associated with substantially lower growth; for emerging markets external debt above 60 percent is associated with lower growth and above 90 percent with severe outcomes
Private sector deleveraging after financial crises (illustrated by US private debt series 1916–2009) tends to depress growth and raise unemployment, compounding public-debt legacies

Policy implication: Debt management (avoiding excessive short-term borrowing and monitoring debt maturity structure) should be central to policy because liability structure affects vulnerability to sudden confidence crises

Assumption: 'Public debt' in the analysis refers to gross central government debt and excludes government-guaranteed private debt; domestic public debt is generally denominated in home currency while external debt is often foreign currency denominated
Caveat: The analysis does not identify causal channels for all debt buildups and may understate adverse effects for peacetime debt explosions versus wartime debt
